column1: Before 1 January 2023, how many major automakers will sell a self-driving passenger vehicle manufactured without a steering wheel?
column6: ['Business', 'Technology']
The advances in self-driving cars are not there yet. Seems extremely unlikely that an autonomous car will not have the option to be driven by a human anytime soon.
To early.

I don't know how an autonomous vehicle handles traffic circles, construction areas, or moving over for emergency vehicles. Other than a fixed route, like a mining truck going back and forth from a mine, I don't know how anyone can have a vehicle with no steering wheel by 2023
Even if they could drive themselves the wheel is too iconic to remove.
The world is not ready to feel like they are out of control, even if the steering wheel does not work.

My understanding of AVs is that we are a ways off from them being reliable enough to be approved without steering wheels. I rode in one on a track at Texas A&M and it was cool, but engineer there told me he didn't expect to see AVs widely used in the next 20 years. Too many issues to work out still. Given this info, seems unlikely one will be ready for sale to public by 2023. Someone may do it as a gimmick, which is why I put some positive probability on 1.

https://emerj.com/ai-adoption-timelines/self-driving-car-timeline-themselves-top-11-automakers/ https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2020-self-driving-car-race/ https://www.vox.com/recode/2020/9/25/21456421/why-self-driving-cars-autonomous-still-years-away https://www.forbes.com/sites/stephenmcbride1/2021/01/06/why-2021-will-be-the-year-self-driving-cars-go-mainstream/?sh=48fca29f4e24

Apart from Tesla whos predictions are the least accurate thing in the world car providers have seized offering predictions on when they will be released which appears they have lost confidence in completing them any time soon. I think it is likely that companies will release taxi services like waymo has done to build up hours before actually offering to sell their vehicles this will mean a slow roll out before they can actually be sold.
Lyft and Uber are the most likely buyers. If they buy one they will buy many; but first they will buy one or two to test them. Waymo and Cruise and GM ar the most likely sellers.

While there is a lot of advancement in the technology around autonomous vehicles the wording of this question is a bit difficult as some companies (like Tesla) are manufacturing self-driving cars (still with steering wheels), whereas other companies are developing the technology to be retrofitted like Waymo with their LIDAR sensors fitted onto multiple other car company cars (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waymo). It also seems that the autonomous vehicle technology is starting to be used, but the initial early adoption market tends to be shared economy vehicles such as taxi services, trucking, and public transport (excluded from this question).
I think that it's to short of a time for people to completely comfortable driving in a car with no steering wheel. Need to progress through having driverless cars with steering wheels first.
first lvl 3s only just on sale and lvl5s are said to be a long way off Cool question
Provided self driving passenger vehicle includes shuttles that can run only on a prescribed route there is some chance.
Too radical of a format.

"Ford has said it will build an autonomous car without a steering wheel or pedals by 2021, while Waymo has begun offering a limited number of rides in fully driverless minivans to its customers in Phoenix, Arizona." https://www.theverge.com/2020/1/21/21075977/cruise-driverless-car-gm-no-steering-wheel-pedals-ev-exclusive-first-look

It seems pretty clear that in the near term (which probably includes <18 months) that autonomous driving will be a complement to piloted driving. Improvements in autonomous driving that expand the scope of situations where drivers don't actively pilot are marginal gains in autonomy. But the jump from a mixed piloted/autonomous system to fully autonomous is pretty big. However, I see a couple of pathways for at least one manufacturer to sell a self-driving vehicle w/o a steering wheel: 1) a small or niche automaker manufactures a vehicle that can be operated fully autonomously w/o a steering wheel in limited situations but nonetheless fits the definition here, and, 2) an automaker manufactures a vehicle that is piloted but has a self-driving mode and uses a joystick-like control. I'm not sure how to think about the likelihood of one vs. more than one selling such a vehicle.

Increased confidence that vehicles will require a steering wheel of some sort (eg. learned that pilots aren't allowed to use autopilot for extended from Hannah Fry's "Hello World"). That lack of "fixed route" makes this tricky. How would "fixed area" count? For instance, would it be impossible for someone like Uber to purchase a vehicle with no driver function that was only allowed to use the centre of LA (wide, flat, clear roads with regularly moving traffic and very few cyclists). Other cities have similar areas. I still stand by that if one company sells, then a few will though.
Holding forecast constant. No news on the subject, but my pessimism remains.
Adjusting closer to crowd forecast. Seems an obvious answer
Laws will prohibit this.

To be "self-driving with no steering wheel" entails 100% autonomy. A "driver" could not even provide input when the vehicle finds itself in a situation where it cannot navigate using its traditional systems. So the real question is:
I am sorry for providing a rather short justification, but the answer seems obvious.
Infrastructure missing to support a car without a wheel. However, scientists and engineers might suprise.
Technology is not there yet. 5-10yrs out, maybe more
last mile-type problems. How do you maneuver where there's no signal like on the 4th floor of an underground garage? Tech isn't quite there en masse.

Since almost all of the vehicles proposed to not have steering wheels are still in concept form at this moment, it seems highly unlikely that one will actually be produced in this short of a timeframe.

Autonomous driving requires much stronger algorithms (ai) than currently available. Current status of the algorithms is good enough for autonomous driving on highways and good weather conditions, but fail in navigating crowded down streets and bad weather conditions. It is expected that it will take several decades before we have algorithms with these capabilities (see for example rebooting ai, for Gary Marcus). Next to the possibility to create vehicles without a steering wheel, there is also the public acceptance. People really have to trust that the vehicles are infallible, higher levels of security must be met (higher than for example the security/trust level for stepping into an Uber) before people will by such a vehicle.

The probability of a self driving car coming isn't that low, but it will take at least 5 and most probably 10 to 20 years before self driving cars ditch the steering wheel completely and still are allowed for circulation.
I'd think Zoox and other start-ups don't count. GM may for their planned shuttle service, but beginning of 2023 in production is too soon.

Most ppl seem to think - still in future. Production, from Major Automaker - who wants it, and speed limited etc. still too soon. *** Major. vs. lots of startups - Amazon Zoox, etc. they are stuck in the past, and worry liability - will take winning new player - laws vs. self driving; risk, so... maybe ... but Production... and risk when more ppl work from home - and gas is cheap?

Vehicles require maintenance. There must always be some ability to maneuver vehicles in confined spaces, and unusual circumstances. I suppose some mfgr might make a plug in terminal for manual control, or develop voice command and control mode, but a steering wheel (or joystick) would still be cheaper and more universally applicable and reliable.
I doubt it would be legal or that people would feel safe in one

The liability and safety issues are too great at this point and I doubt people will want to buy a vehicle without a steering wheel until the self driving technology has been proven at mass scale which will likely take longer than the timeframe of this question.
It's possible one may for a small test market but, as a generally available product, this seems very unlikely. The legal and regulatory environment just aren't ready.
Non production prototypes will be demonstrated
This continues to be a silly question. Base case: how many elevators don't have buttons? How long did it take for this to happen at all? How much easier are the controls for elevators?

Getting self driving working on it's own is trick enough. Only Waymo really has shown it can do it so far. The Tesla vs Lidar usage issue is ongoing and it's not clear if Tesla is able yet to us it's way of doing things to get full self driving. The idea of doing it with out a steering wheel is far off unfortunately.

I assume "demoing" or prototypes don't count. I assume this means "in production" cars coming off an assembly line. At this stage I think it's a market demand issue - too many people currently buying cars are used to having a steering wheel.
At this point, this is an equally unlikely tossup between "one" and "none," with a distinct possibility of "some."
would servo accuating joy sticks count?

The problems seem more human focussed. The technology is fairly secure (based on feedback from a friend at the Oxford Robotics Institute), but the sale needs to be legalised. The question specifically states the lack of a steering wheel which makes this easier. No matter how much you train a program, it can still meet unknown situations. In the case of an AV, it would then be very useful information to understand how a human might tackle that problem (from the manufacturer's perspective). Further, autonomous vehicles may be legally required to have a back up system to allow for driver control, similar to how must brake systems require a physical back up to a computerised system (governmental perspective). I have put the probability of 0 at 90% because there may be countries which make technology pushes which require flagship events/publicity. Showing a few steering wheel-less cars could form part of that. Should that be legalised, I expect the technology is safe enough that more than one manufacturer will sell a vehicle to some wealthy customers, with those customers mostly making the purchase for the novelty factor. In my opinion, the least likely result of those presented above is a single company for that reason.
The driver needs to take control at any given time.
It will be none or many
If one does, they will likely be out of business in 2024.
Neither software nor hardware is ready for level 5 autonomy yet. Exceedingly unlikely to be achieved in the next two years.

I understand that I need to be more specific in the future. Presently it appears that the shift of the industry is towards autonomous goods delivery so that the industry has more time to develop algorithms, while collecting revenue to fund the research. Tesla is presently Level 2 autonomous driving level and this would require to Level 5.
The technology is definitely there and working - without steering wheel.
Psychologically speaking, I don't think the public will go for it. People like the illusion of control.

Before 1 January 2023 we will likely see concept cars without a steering wheel (most likely from Tesla). Probability some jurisdiction enacts regulation making totally non-human controllable cars legal by 2023: 2% Companies might see PR value of being first to market. There's also a possibility that one company sells a non-human controllable car as a tech demonstration/toy for very rich people that can only be used on private property. In this scenario, it would most likely be one company catering to an uptra-niche market.
These are the same guys who will be building using solid state batteries in that timeframe and offering robotaxi services.
If not any then would be a few as rules/ tech change, say 6

I think it's probable that a show vehicle from Tesla will have no steering wheel in the next two and a half years. Probability some jurisdiction enacts regulation making totally non-human controllable cars legal by 2023: 2% Probability a company sells such a car either as a non-street legal model: 10% If such cars are legal somewhere, I think it's unlikely but not impossible that at least one brand delivers a car by then. The most likely scenario is only one brand (most likely Tesla) doing so, but there's at least some chance that several try to gain the PR value of being first to market. There's also a possibility that one company sells a non-human controllable car as a tech demonstration/toy for very rich people that can only be used on private property. In this scenario, it would most likely be one company catering to an uptra-niche market.

There are too many technological obstacles still to overcome notwithstanding regulatory. However, if it's possible by such an early date, there'd be not 1 but 2 car makers managing it. Google & Tesla.

Updating and adjusting my forecast. I think the question refers to a traditional, round, steering wheel, even if it is hidden in the dashboard. However, I think any other human interactive device (PS4 controller, VR glove) would count as a positive answer. See, for example, "BMW patents joystick to replace steering wheel in autonomous cars" https://www.bmwblog.com/2020/07/29/bmw-patents-joystick-in-autonomous-cars/
I think the last estimate was too high. Musks statements are actually evidence in favor of full self-driving (https://electrek.co/2020/07/23/tesla-self-driving-elon-musk-house-to-work/)

Two points here: 1.) I am presuming that by steering wheel, the intent is the round traditional physical steering wheel 2.) Based on that I do believe it is possible there will be cars produced in that timeframe with no traditional steering wheel but instead the driver will be able to override self-driving at any point and steer through other means such as a digital touch pad with a simulation of a steering wheel with haptic feedback, orva joystick-like controller, or even through head or eye movements detected by cameras within the car.

Right now we have level 3 self-driving cars, if a vehicle was produced without a steering wheel it would be squarely in level 5. The most possible scenario where this happens is self-driving ride share vehicles that only operate in one area. Volkswagen doesn't predict this will happen until after 2025 [1]. GM's Cruise is probably closer to level 5 but recently laid off 8% of their workforce [2]. True automation was already being looked at pessimistically before the pandemic, but in the current crisis 2023 is simply too optimistic.
Playing chicken with the crowd: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-tech-handsfree-focus/hands-free-automakers-race-to-next-level-of-not-quite-self-driving-cars-idUSKCN24G14O
https://www.forbes.com/sites/johnkoetsier/2020/07/09/elon-musk-tesla-will-have-level-5-self-driving-cars-this-year/#7a1050e52d1d

I think this is too early for a car without any sort of manual control, but I think there is a reasonable chance a manufacturer will have a model with some sort of backup manual control method that takes the form of something other than a steering wheel. One potential justification would be as a means to discourage manual driving as the default mode. Saab made a car in the '90's I think that used a joystick.
First hunch is That it is not very likely. If not 0, then it seems equally likely that there are 1, 2 or 3+
Micro-increase by 1pp for 0 because of price reduction for autopilot
I think that's too soon for the public and regulators to be comfortable with the idea, let alone for it to be possible that the technology is ready for that by then.

Updating and elaborating. Starting with initial numbers from Crowd forecast. I currently feel AI will not be advanced enough in time to allow a major manufacturer to sell a self-driving vehicle without an emergency human-intervention option (i.e., human take control, which implies a steering wheel.) Question: Does sell = mass produce? I'm guessing no. Question: Does a steering wheel hidden in the dash that only pops out on demand/in emergencies count? I would say yes. Question: Does a PS4 controller count as a steering wheel? I'm guessing yes. Question: Does a joystick count as a steering wheel? I'm guessing yes. I'm guessing steering wheel = human steering interface. If a PS4 controller counts as no, I might raise the odds a little. Advancements in VR might also raise the odds (gloves instead of a steering wheel). Still, given current level of AI, government restriction, and insurance requirements, I'm sticking with 98% no.

The AI software will not solve all real world situations well enough in that timeframe. Consumers will not be ready to place their lives in the hands of driving robots. And legislators will not permit such perceived high-risk vehicles on the roads.

AI progress quickly reaches the point of diminishing returns. This is where each increment of improvement costs much more than the one before. Eventually the cost of the next step exceeds the value of the improvement. They may be able to make a no steering wheel car but it may costs as much as an F-22 fighter.
Slow adoption of current self driving technology along with regulatory hurdles.

While I believe it is unlikely, technological advances is a very competitive game. Most likely a steering wheelless car would never be anything more than a company “flexing” to demonstrate that it is feasible I imagine it will be a few years further into the future before a mass produced car without a steering wheel would be palatable to the public and profitable to the company. And even then I imagine it would not be popular for independently owned cars. A tech that would most likely be used in taxis and shuttle buses. I believe Tesla is already working on the technology and others will quickly follow suit. Regulation may be more of a hurdle than anything but it could less regulated countries that become the test ground for this new driving technology.

The time line for production of a new car from concept to dealerships is about two years for new models or very significant changes. I consider a fully autonomous vehicle to be a very significant change, and it will take more than two years to produce such a vehicle. To the best of my knowledge, no manufacturer is actively producing a level 5 autonomous vehicle. People are still working on level 2 and 3. Zoox is a notable exception, but they are still far off of a production vehicle.

Selling a vehicle without a steering wheel is the key phrase to this question. There will likely be press and news a solid three years before it occurs. No major auto maker is going to produce such a vehicle, except possibly for a very unique use case or marketing effort.
Cars without steering wheels would be in the developed stage of autonomous driving. Currently we are between stage 0 and 1.
The legal system does not have a mechanism to assign liability for autonomous cars. They won’t sell one until this exists.
Level 5 driving will not be available by 2023.
Unless Liability Laws change Globally, No Manufacturer accept responsibility for all the failure of autonomous systems.

Truly autonomous vehicle's capable of functioning as well as an attentive human driver are a bit like fusion reactors - we have been "nearly there" for a while now, and "next year" is always the year. Even if there are major breakthroughs in the next year, I do not see a manufacturer removing ( or being allowed to remove) the steering wheel until we have several years of true autonomous driving, with many millions of autonomous miles booked at very high safety levels. Until then there will be some way for humans to take control. I could see someone introducing a joystick or other "drive by wire" control that seems _less_ like a steering wheel, but it will still have the same function that the wheel had - to make the car point away from barricades and other cars if/when the computer hits a corner case it can't handle...

The Vast majority of the public will still want the ability to drive like they always have, even if they use an automatic driving feature. Also most people won’t feel safe unless there is a human override steering system. It’s possible that there will be a model with a joystick used to steer, but I can’t see a market big enough to support the investment in R&D. And, there are still a lot of limits with the AI for self driving’s I’m not sure it will be possible to go without a steering wheel to override computer malfunctions.
Lack customer confidence in this
development is ongoing but human nature will not give up control
I would love a # of cars cut off ... if >10 this is a good forecast especially given "no steering wheel".
There is a outside chance that multiple manufacturers will push forward together via an industry consortium or association, if anyone even steps up to tackle this.

The liability is too great to introduce autonomous vehicles for conventional driving routes. Moreover, passengers Will be highly skeptical of using this mode of transportation. They will be made comfortable by access to this functionality on fixed routes with sufficient controls (not introducing random human drivers). Once the public becomes comfortable with fixed routes, then the social mindset will be ready to consider purchasing autonomous vehicles.

Even if the technology exists to safely commercially implement said technology by 1 January 2023, the world's regulatory frameworks and governing laws are not equipped to address larger issues which the proposition of driverless cars without the physical capability for human beings to directly control present. Manufacturers will not commercialize a technology for which there is no market for them to sell into. Manufacturers may well demonstrate the viability of driverless cars without steering wheels via prototype halo vehicles; however, they will not be mass produced within this decade. The automotive industry as a whole first needs to transition to EV vehicles en masse before
I don’t think the public is ready for it yet.

Only two companies have begun making cars without steering wheels, (GM and VW), but GM's car won't be for sale to consumers. We will need to see autonomous cars for at least 3 successful years without accidents before people trust them enough to use without steering wheels.
Nuro is interesting , would not be surprised if they were bought up or merged and therefore included in the top 50 list.
Tesla appears to be quite capable of removing steering wheel from their vehicles. https://electrek.co/2019/04/23/tesla-design-without-steering-wheel-elon-musk/
It seems unlikely that regulators will allow autonomous vehicles to be manufactured and sold without the ability for the driver to over-ride the system and take control of the steering.

The industry seriously underestimated the difficulties posed by a Level 5 automatic driving (without a steering wheel would mean a car that can self drive under ANY circumstance), but they have been lately coming to their senses - https://emerj.com/ai-adoption-timelines/self-driving-car-timeline-themselves-top-11-automakers/.

As others are noting, there are a lot of requirements currently around steering wheels and other driving accouterments that a computer doesn't need in federal (US) standards [1]. There is progress with the fixed-routes that have received exemptions [2], but that is out-of-scope for this question. Bloomberg gives a rundown of how often fully autonomous cars have been pushed out: there was a lot of optimism for 2021, before COVID [3,5]. There is a lawsuit against Tesla [4] that may further push out interest in Japan, in particular, where the accident occurred as well as influence US regulation.
The question is "major" automakers, I don't think even Tesla can do it in less than 3 years. I have to choose 99% because there is no selection of 100%.

Tesla is out - they will include a steering wheel. No one besides waymo seems like they have made significant progress on the software front. Even if the software is available, it will likely take time for automakers to have everything integrated to sell

There are too many regulatory and legal hurdles to overcome before Jan 1 2023 to allow any OEM to sell a car without steering wheel that is allowed to drive on the road. Thinking about Elevators here - automated elevators were invented around the early 1900s, but it took until a massive boom of skyscrapers in NYC (1930s) for automated elevators to be adopted by consumers. That's a slightly different Q&A than what's asked here, but I think it's relevant.
The degree of AI necessary to operate in unusual or emergency conditions will not be available. Vehicles impossible to operate manually may be legislatively curtailed.

Now I'm assuming the question also covers joysticks or another mechanical, direct driver to wheels interface. It will never happen, because second law of thermodynamics means a car will break down. And when it does, it will need a device to steer it off the road.
to soon
Regulators will not allow a fully autonomous vehicle until 2023

Sold. Great points have been made and I think of 1) the futurist leaning of thinking where we imagine flying cars and plastic jumpsuits and 2) the fact that rarely the future/technology looks how we predict or imagine. I think the Cybertruck steering wheel is a logical next step in the evolution of rendering the steering wheel obsolete. That said, progress happens dramatically and in ways we can't anticipate. Legislation and infrastructure are major obstacles here.
Adjusting...

Litigation issues in the US will prevent adoption. Regulatory issues related to driving on public highways. Infrastructure will not catch up. Self driving vehicles will be or are in use in closed and controlled environments such as mines, areas of public display (zoo, amusement parks) and other regions where control is possible.
Based on @Wildwood2000's comment [1].
Autonomous driving will emerge as an option, no point in limiting manual driving at this point.
GM has the cruise and 2-3 years is a long time.
Revising after more insight from other forecasters and more research.

Manufacturing a vehicle with only ONE usage model this decade seems a stretch. Such a vehicle is inherently limited and manufacturers need to sell in the millions to make money. You don't save much on costs by eliminating the steering wheel, but you radicaly limit your market. By the end of this decade any thing can happen, in 2022, very doubtful from a major, the vehilce would need to be in test now to be released in 2023 and technology is not there yet.
I lack the imagination to bet on a positive number here.

Just because Tesla has a car that will stop at a red light (most of the time), this doesn't mean they are anywhere close to a fully self driving car. They are a long way from trusting a car to deal with every kid that runs into the road, or every construction site, or heavy snow. It will be keep your hands on the wheel just in case for quite a while yet.
Level 5 automation means full automation in all conditions Needed to resolve this probability equals no steering wheel
1.) Don't know if this counts, but I have experience with Tesla autopilot and the incremental improvements it makes, and January 2023 just isn't enough time, at least based on that.

This is difficult. Articles like this (https://emerj.com/ai-adoption-timelines/self-driving-car-timeline-themselves-top-11-automakers/) include a lot of quotes from automakers about deadlines that keep getting pushed further and further back. Seems like one of those effects where the people working on a group project all seriously underestimate the time it will take them to complete the project.

I don't think it's a concept worth pursuing, as buyers will be skeptical for a few more years. However, there have been loads of concept cars without steering wheel on the recent motor shows, so it's highly likely there will be a pioneering company which will have a shot at this market and sell a car of this specifications in a trial and error mode, since it will be a USP advantage and there are in the medium term large risk premiums to pocket.

I love the long term time-frame. I need to give this a long look, but I'll start here as a baseline: reason being that on the one hand it is hard to imagine i.e. the public accepting this change and lack of control (mainly boomers); then again, technology has a cascading effect...
